desc: To arise is to happen.
exam: Difficulties arose with his computer because it was old.

desc: A benefactor is a person who gives money to help someone.
exam: The student’s benefactor gave him money to spend on his studies.

desc: A blacksmith is a person who makes things out of metal.
exam: The blacksmith pounded the piece of metal until it was flat.

desc: When someone is charitable, they help people who are in need.
exam: My sister was charitable enough to help me buy my first house.

desc: A chimney is a tall pipe used to carry smoke out of a building.
exam: The cat was on the roof sitting next to the chimney.

desc: To compensate is to pay someone for the time they spent doing something.
exam: Her boss compensated her for the extra work she did last week.

desc: If you encounter something, you meet or come close to it.
exam: I encountered a sea turtle while I was swimming.

desc: To exceed is to be more than something.
exam: Since I exceeded my limit, I decided to get rid of my credit cards.

desc: To forge is to make or produce, especially with difficulty.
exam: Stacy and Heather forged their friendship when they were teenagers.

desc: People who are humble do not believe that they are better than other people.
exam: Even though Bob is the smartest boy in his class, he is humble.

desc: Iron is a strong metal that is used to make many objects.
exam: The horse had shoes made of iron.

desc: A ladder is an object that is used to climb up and down things.
exam: He used a ladder to climb to the top of his tree house.

desc: If people are modest, they do not think that they are too important.
exam: Derek is very modest for someone who is so rich.

desc: To occupy a place is to live, work, or be there.
exam: Kevin and Alice occupied the chairs and had a long discussion.

desc: A penny is a coin worth one cent.
exam: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is on the penny.

desc: To preach is to talk about and promote a religious idea.
exam: Aaron often preached about living an honest life.

desc: To prosper is to be successful or make a lot of money.
exam: Frank’s new business finally prospered after many years of hard work.

desc: A province is a small area that is controlled by a country.
exam: Canada is divided into several different provinces.

desc: Satisfaction is a feeling you get when you do or receive something good.
exam: Brad was filled with satisfaction when he saw what was for dinner.

desc: To sustain something is to keep it going.
exam: Wind power is a clean way to sustain a city with energy.

desc: To acquire something is to gain possession of it.
exam: Tina acquired a strange package yesterday.

desc: If something is awkward, it is embarrassing and uncomfortable.
exam: After dropping his coffee cup, Robbie felt awkward.

desc: A caretaker is a person who takes care of very young, old, or sick people.
exam: My grandmother’s caretaker helps her get around the house.

desc: To deceive someone is to make them believe something that is not true.
exam: He tried to deceive his friends as they were playing a game.

desc: To discourage someone is to make them feel less excited about something.
exam: Mr. Perry discouraged the students from quitting school.

desc: If something is fake, it is made to look real in order to trick people.
exam: The model was wearing fake eyelashes.

desc: Hatred is a strong feeling of not liking someone or something.
exam: I have a hatred for the taste of medicine.

desc: A hut is a house made of wood, grass, or mud that has only one or two rooms.
exam: We all went into the hut to sleep.

desc: If something is inferior, it is not as good as something else.
exam: Cars built a hundred years ago are inferior to ones built today.

desc: A lodge is a house in the mountains, used by people who hunt or fish.
exam: During our ski trip, we stayed at a lodge.

desc: To neglect someone or something is to not take care of it properly.
exam: William neglected his room, so it is a complete mess.

desc: A newcomer is a person who has recently arrived at a place or a group.
exam: The students happily welcomed the newcomer to the school.

desc: An offense is behavior that is wrong or breaks a law.
exam: Stealing a car is a very serious offense.

desc: To overlook something is to not notice it, or to not realize that it is important.
exam: Brenda overlooked the last step and had a bad fall.

desc: To repay is to pay back or to reward someone or something.
exam: She repaid her friend for all of his hard work with a small gift.

desc: If something is ridiculous, it is silly or strange.
exam: Steve looked ridiculous with those huge blue sunglasses.

desc: If something is satisfactory, it is good enough.
exam: Mina often received satisfactory grades since she studied so hard.

desc: A shepherd is a person who protects and cares for sheep.
exam: The shepherd moved the sheep to another field.

desc: To venture is to go to a place that may be dangerous.
exam: Even though it was dangerous, they ventured up the mountain.

desc: Wheat is a plant which makes grain. Wheat grain is used to make bread.
exam: The field of golden wheat was ready to be harvested.

desc: An alley is a narrow road behind houses or buildings.
exam: The alley behind my house looks dirty.

desc: An ax is a tool used to cut wood.
exam: She used an ax to cut some wood for the fire.

desc: A bunch is a group of the same things.
exam: She was hungry, so she ate the entire bunch of grapes.

desc: A chore is a job that you have to do but don’t like.
exam: It’s Nikki’s chore to do the dishes every Tuesday and Wednesday night.

desc: When something is decent, it is OK or good enough.
exam: Eric did a decent job painting the fence.

desc: Disgrace is a feeling of shame.
exam: He felt a sense of disgrace after failing his big exam.

desc: The elbow is the middle part of a person’s arm that lets you bend it.
exam: She pointed to her elbow to show me where she hurt herself.

desc: When you are grateful for something, you are happy that it happened.
exam: The girls were grateful to have a chance to spend time with their grandfather.

desc: To irritate means to annoy someone.
exam: She was irritated when her brother told her that he had lost her camera.

desc: To kid is to make a joke to make someone believe something which is not true.
exam: I am not really mad. I was kidding when I said I was angry.

desc: When something is loose, it is not held in place well.
exam: The bolt was loose, so I tightened it with the wrench.

desc: To offend someone means to make them angry or upset.
exam: They were both offended by what they had said to each other.

desc: When something happens overnight, it happens during the night.
exam: The campers stayed in the tent overnight.

desc: To persist means to keep doing something even when it is hard.
exam: Even though the lesson was difficult, he persisted until he understood.

desc: A pine is a type of tree that is tall and thin.
exam: There were many beautiful pine trees in the forest.

desc: A scar is a mark on the skin after a wound heals.
exam: The monster had horrible scars on his cheek and forehead.

desc: A sensation is a feeling a person gets from their senses.
exam: Mom got a painful sensation in her head from the loud noise.

desc: A sled is a small vehicle that you use on snow.
exam: Marvin likes to ride his sled down the hill in winter.

desc: To tease someone means to laugh at or make fun of them.
exam: Jake teased Charlie because he was the new student.

desc: A valentine is someone you love or admire with great affection.
exam: Harry wanted Molly to be his valentine.

desc: When a plant blooms, it makes flowers.
exam: Roses look so pretty when they bloom.

desc: If something is compact, it is smaller than normal.
exam: A laptop computer is much more compact than a desktop model.

desc: A curl is a small piece of something with a round shape.
exam: The colorful ribbons were bent into curls.

desc: To decay is to be destroyed naturally.
exam: The old wooden house was slowly decaying.

desc: Dessert is a sweet food that you eat after a meal.
exam: Kayla wants ice cream for dessert.

desc: To dip something is to put part of it into a liquid for a short time.
exam: Laurel dipped her strawberry into the chocolate.

desc: If something is distant, it is far away.
exam: Michael could barely see the distant island.

desc: An eclipse is an occasion when the moon moves in front of the sun.
exam: A complete eclipse of the sun is a very rare occurrence.

desc: A fairy is a small, magic creature with wings.
exam: There are usually fairies in fantasy stories.

desc: Grace is a quality of moving in a smooth, relaxed and attractive way.
exam: The ballerina danced with grace.

desc: Leisure is time when you do not have to do work.
exam: Eve likes to listen to music in her leisure time.

desc: Mankind is all of the world’s people.
exam: All of mankind has to work to make this a better world.

desc: Passion is a very strong feeling of wanting to do something.
exam: She had a passion for dancing.

desc: A pillow is something that you put your head on when you sleep.
exam: When I travel, I usually take along my favorite pillow.

desc: A pulse is the beat of the heart.
exam: The doctor checked the patient’s pulse by feeling his wrist.

desc: To refresh someone is to make them feel less hot or tired.
exam: The baby was refreshed after taking a cool bath.

desc: To sneeze is to suddenly blow air out of your nose and mouth.
exam: He sneezed after smelling the flower.

desc: A spice is a flavor for food and drinks.
exam: Two common spices found in many homes are salt and pepper.

desc: To whistle is to make a sound by putting your lips together and blowing.
exam: Ashe was listening to music, Daryl whistled.

desc: Wool is the hair that a sheep has.
exam: Grandma wants to use the blue wool to knit me a sweater.

desc: To acquaint is to get to know something or someone.
exam: Nancy acquainted herself with the new computer.

desc: A cemetery is where people are buried when they die.
exam: Some people are scared of cemeteries.

desc: To curse someone or something is to hope that bad things happen to them.
exam: The witch cursed the village.

desc: A disguise is something you wear so people cannot tell who you are.
exam: Everyone knew that it was Dad in the Santa disguise.

desc: If something is fancy, it is nicer than normal.
exam: Their table was all set for a fancy dinner.

desc: A flashlight is a small electric light that you carry in your hand.
exam: We took a flashlight when we went camping.

desc: A hood is part of a coat that goes over your head.
exam: She put on her hood to keep her head warm.

desc: An inhabitant is a person who lives in a certain place.
exam: The number of inhabitants in the countryside is increasing.

desc: To nourish something is to give it food that it needs to live.
exam: A good mother will nourish her baby every day.

desc: A pirate is a sailor who steals things from other boats.
exam: Pirates are very scary characters.

desc: A publication is something printed, like a newspaper or book.
exam: She’s been a subscriber to that publication for over ten years.

desc: A riddle is a question that is difficult to answer but meant to be funny.
exam: I could not answer Wendy’s riddle, but it made me laugh.

desc: When something rots, it slowly gets softer and is destroyed.
exam: The old log began to rot in the forest.

desc: To scare means to cause one to feel frightened.
exam: I was scared by the sight of the monster.

desc: If something will happen shortly, it will happen very soon.
exam: My workday will end shortly.

desc: A skeleton is the bones of a body.
exam: There is a skeleton in the science classroom.

desc: If something spoils, it turns bad or rots.
exam: We left the fruit out too long, and it spoiled.

desc: If a person starves, they do not get enough to eat and sometimes die.
exam: During the war, many people starved.

desc: A thrill is an exciting feeling.
exam: The boys enjoy the thrill of surfing a big wave.

desc: If something is wicked, it is very bad or evil.
exam: My boss is a very wicked man.

desc: To alert someone is to tell or warn them about something.
exam: The fire alarm alerted us that there was a problem.

desc: A broadcast is a television or radio show.
exam: We watched the broadcast of the local news on TV.

desc: A bulletin is a news report that talks about very recent and important events.
exam: There was a live bulletin reporting on the economy of the city.

desc: A bump is a small raised area on a surface.
exam: The monkey got a bump on his head because he was hit by a rock.

desc: To chop something means to cut it into pieces with a tool.
exam: Mom chopped some vegetables to put into the stew.

desc: A closet is a small room used to store things.
exam: Marie has many clothes inside o f her closet.

desc: To console someone who is sad means to make them comforted.
exam: When my dog ran away, my dad consoled me.

desc: A district is a small part of a city, county, state, or country.
exam: I live in a residential district of Seattle, Washington.

desc: A drawer is a small part in furniture that is used to store things.
exam: I put my clothes into the empty drawers.

desc: To endure something tough means to do or go through it.
exam: She had to endure her husband shouting all day long.

desc: To execute someone means to kill them as a legal punishment.
exam: Some people are executed for serious crimes.

desc: To grasp something means to hold it.
exam: He grasped the bag o f money tightly.

desc: When something is in the rear of something, it is in the back.
exam: The man loaded the rear of his truck with boxes.

desc: A senator is someone who makes laws for a state.
exam: The young senator promised to make laws that would help the people.

desc: A skull is the hard part of your head. Your brain is inside of it.
exam: The brain is protected by the skull.

desc: To stir something means to mix it using something small, like a spoon.
exam: Mom stirred the batter until it was smooth.

desc: To tap something is to hit it lightly.
exam: He tapped the keys of the keyboard to write a short word.

desc: When something is tremendous, it is very large.
exam: The Earth’s oceans are filled with a tremendous amount of water.

desc: When something is underneath something else, it is below or lower than it.
exam: The roots of a tree are located underneath the ground.

desc: A worm is a small animal with a long, thin body.
exam: Worms are often used to help catch fish.

desc: To abandon something is to leave it forever or for a long time.
exam: The old room had been abandoned years before.

desc: If someone is ambitious, they want to be rich or successful.
exam: Kendra had to be ambitious to get into medical school.

desc: When a dog barks, it makes a short, loud noise.
exam: The dog barked loudly and frighteningly.

desc: A bay is an area near the ocean where the land goes inward.
exam: The Golden Gate Bridge crosses San Francisco Bay.

desc: If someone is brilliant, they are very smart.
exam: My younger sister is brilliant for someone her age.

desc: Your chin is the hard part at the bottom of your face.
exam: Luke pointed to the hair on his chin.

desc: A complaint is something you say to tell people that you don’t like something.
exam: Mom said she didn’t want to hear my brother’s complaints.

desc: When someone is deaf, they cannot hear.
exam: Susan was born deaf.

desc: To be enthusiastic about something is to be excited by or interested in it.
exam: The man was enthusiastic about his job.

desc: An expedition is a long trip, usually to a place very far away.
exam: They got into their spaceship to begin their expedition.

desc: The horizon is where the sky looks like it meets the ground.
exam: The sun clipped below the horizon.

desc: To be loyal to something or someone is to agree to always help them.
exam: The three friends are very loyal to each other.

desc: The mayor is the person in charge of a city.
exam: The mayor o f my hometown is quite a powerful speaker.

desc: If something is mutual, it is felt in the same way by two or more people.
exam: Robert likes Sarah. The feeling is mutual.

desc: If someone is overweight, they are very fat.
exam: Roger eats too much, so now he’s overweight.

desc: A refuge is a place where you go to be safe.
exam: When it started to rain, she found refuge in the house.

desc: To restore something is to put it back the way it was.
exam: Victor restored the old car.

desc: To rub something is to push on it and move your hand back and forth.
exam: Mom’s feet were sore, so she rubbed them.

desc: Your senses are how you see, taste, hear, feel and smell.
exam: It would be hard to live without your five senses.

desc: A veterinarian is a doctor that takes care of animals.
exam: Wanda became a veterinarian because she loves dogs.

desc: An anniversary is a day that celebrates something from the past.
exam: My parents went out to eat for their wedding anniversary.

desc: Arithmetic is math.
exam: I like to study arithmetic at school.

desc: To be ashamed is to feel upset because you did something wrong or bad.
exam: He was ashamed when he found out that I knew about his past.

desc: To burst is to suddenly break open or apart.
exam: The bomb burst over the city.

desc: A carpenter is a person who builds things with wood.
exam: We hired a carpenter to make a cupboard.

desc: Coal is a hard black rock that you burn for heat.
exam: Many power stations burn coal to produce energy.

desc: A couch is a long, soft seat that many people can sit on.
exam: Kim and M artin’s new couch was very expensive.

desc: When a liquid drips, just a little bit falls at a time.
exam: I heard water dripping from the faucet.

desc: If something is elegant, it is very fancy and pleasing.
exam: In Japan, women wear elegant kimonos on special occasions.

desc: Fabric is cloth used to make clothes, furniture, etc.
exam: The towels were made from a soft fabric.

desc: The highlands are high areas of land, usually with mountains.
exam: The man had a small home in the highlands.

desc: Ivory is a white, hard substance that comes from elephants.
exam: The elephant’s long ivory tusks looked very impressive.

desc: A mill is a building where flour is made.
exam: The farmer took his wheat to the mill to make it into flour.

desc: A needle is a small, sharp piece of metal that you use to make or fix clothes.
exam: I used a needle to fix the hole in my pants.

desc: To polish something is to rub it in order to make it shiny.
exam: Mark spent all morning polishing his shoes for the wedding.

desc: To sew means to put pieces of cloth together using string.
exam: I learned to sew when I was a little girl.

desc: A shed is a small building where you store things like tools.
exam: We have a small shed in the backyard for storage.

desc: A thread is a thin piece of string.
exam: I have many different colors of thread at home.

desc: To trim something is to cut it a little bit.
exam: I had my hair trimmed this afternoon.

desc: If something goes upwards, it moves vertically higher.
exam: The kite went upwards further and further.

desc: To ail a person or group is to cause difficulty or pain.
exam: My brother went to the doctor to see what was ailing him.

desc: An ally is someone who agrees to help or support you.
exam: I was happy to find many allies who shared the same opinion as me.

desc: To boast is to talk about how good you are.
exam: We all became tired o f listening to him boast about him self all day.

desc: To bounce is to move something up and away from a surface after hitting it.
exam: Owen bounced the ball on the ground.

desc: A bully is a person who is mean to others.
exam: The two bullies always picked on the smaller, weaker kids.

desc: Carbohydrates are substances in foods like bread that give you energy.
exam: Carbohydrates like rice are a good source o f energy for active people.

desc: To crawl is to move slowly on your hands and knees.
exam: The baby crawled across the floor.

desc: To defeat someone is to beat them in a game or battle.
exam: The champion defeated the challenger in the boxing match.

desc: A dial is the front of a clock.
exam: I looked at the dial to see what time it was.

desc: When someone or something is dominant, they are stronger than others.
exam: The gorilla is one o f the dominant animals in the jungle.

desc: If you show mercy, you choose not to punish or harm someone.
exam: He asked his boss for mercy and to not fire him.

desc: To nod is to move your head up and down.
exam: I nodded my head as I listened to the song.

desc: An opponent is someone who fights against you.
exam: On the field, our opponents were too good for us.

desc: To quarrel is to argue or fight.
exam: Billy quarreled with his wife about buying a new house.

desc: A rival is someone that is trying to keep you from getting what you want.
exam: The three rivals were all competing for the same job.

desc: When a part of your body is sore, it hurts.
exam: After lifting the heavy box, Mona’s back was sore.

desc: To sting is to cause pain by pushing a sharp part into the skin.
exam: The needle stung my arm and made me say, “ Ouch!”

desc: To strain is to try very hard.
exam: Casey strained to lift the heavy box.

desc: Torture is something that causes you physical or mental pain.
exam: Greg thought that writing the essay was torture.

desc: To wrestle is to play a game where you try to push someone to the floor.
exam: My dad loved to wrestle when he was in high school.

desc: Absence is the state of something being away.
exam: There is an absence of sand in the hourglass.

desc: If you say something aloud, you say it so that others can hear you.
exam: My father often reads stories aloud to me and my sister.

desc: If someone is bald, they have no hair.
exam: My oldest brother is bald.

desc: A blanket is a piece of cloth that you use to keep warm or to sit upon.
exam: I laid a blanket on the ground so that we could have a picnic.

desc: To creep is to move quietly and slowly.
exam: The cat slowly crept down the tree.

desc: Divorce is an event in which a marriage is ended.
exam: Divorce rates have increased in the past twenty years.

desc: To imitate someone is to do exactly what they do.
exam: He imitated his favorite superhero by putting on a costume.

desc: An infant is a baby.
exam: The infant cried all night.

desc: To kidnap someone is to take them illegally.
exam: She was terrified to find out her son was kidnapped.

desc: A nap is a short sleep, usually during the day.
exam: I took a short nap because I stayed up late last night.

desc: You use nowhere to say that a place or thing does not exist.
exam: Unfortunately, water was nowhere to be found.

desc: To pat something is to hit it softly with your hand.
exam: I patted some lotion onto my face.

desc: Relief is a feeling you get when something bad or challenging ends.
exam: I felt a sense of relief when I heard the good news.

desc: To reproduce is to make something exactly how someone else did it.
exam: The children tried to reproduce their house using toy blocks.

desc: To rhyme is to have the same sounds at the end of a word.
exam: Humpty Dumpty is an old rhyme that children learn in school.

desc: To suck is to put something in your mouth and try to get flavor out of it.
exam: The baby sucked milk from her bottle.

desc: If something is urgent, it is important and needs to be done now.
exam: He had to leave now; it was urgent.

desc: To vanish is to go away suddenly.
exam: All the passengers vanished from the train station.

desc: A wagon is a cart you use to carry heavy things.
exam: He used his wagon to carry some of his gifts.

desc: A wrinkle is a line on a person’s face that happens as they get old.
exam: My grandfather has some wrinkles on his face.

desc: If something is abnormal, it is strange or not normal.
exam: Her idea of art is a bit too abnormal for me.

desc: Bamboo is a hard plant with thin branches and leaves.
exam: Outside his home, there is a lot of bamboo.

desc: A blossom is a flower or group of flowers.
exam: There were colorful blossoms in the yard.

desc: A compass is a device used to tell what direction one is going.
exam: A compass is an important tool to have when you are traveling.

desc: A dialect is a regional variety of language showing where you are from.
exam: People from the U.K. have a different dialect of English from those in the U.K.

desc: If someone is dishonest, they do not tell the truth.
exam: She was being dishonest when she copied the answers from his test.

desc: A dwarf is a creature from stories that often looks like a short, hairy man.
exam: The dwarf had a pleasant look on his face.

desc: An ecosystem is a group of plants and animals in an area.
exam: The river’s ecosystem not only includes fish but other insects and plants too.

desc: If something is fatal, it causes death.
exam: They passed away in a fatal car crash.

desc: If someone is impatient, they are not able to wait for things.
exam: Bob was so impatient that he could barely wait for the light to turn green.

desc: A leaf is the flat green thing on trees or bushes.
exam: In the fall, the leaves on the trees change colors.

desc: A manuscript is an old book or paper written by hand.
exam: The manuscript was written over 150 years ago.

desc: A marsh is a type of wet land covered with grasses and short plants.
exam: The marsh looked so lovely against the mountains.

desc: Patience is the ability to wait for something without becoming upset.
exam: Sue’s patience was rewarded by catching her very first fish.

desc: Perfume is a good-smelling liquid that girls wear.
exam: When she wore her perfume, everyone said she smelled great.

desc: A pond is a very small area of water.
exam: The ducks swam in the pond.

desc: A proverb is a short saying that tells you something important.
exam: The proverb “egg on your face” means you’ve done something embarrassing.

desc: A pursuit is a chase.
exam: The dinosaur was in pursuit of the caveman.

desc: To recite something means to repeat or say aloud in front of a group.
exam: Katie recited the Pledge of Allegiance in class.

desc: A wilderness is an area where no people live.
exam: If you are not careful, you can get lost in the wilderness.

desc: To anticipate something is to think that it will happen.
exam: Carrie anticipated the arrival of her baby.

desc: A barrel is a round thing that you can keep liquids in.
exam: There was an empty barrel outside the house.

desc: A beam is a heavy bar.
exam: Modern skyscrapers are made with several beams.

desc: If something is casual, it is relaxed or simple.
exam: You can wear casual clothes to the party like jeans.

desc: Caution is care and attention in order to avoid danger.
exam: Please use the power saw with caution. It is very dangerous.

desc: If something is contrary to something else, it is the opposite.
exam: It isn’t warm outside at all. On the contrary, it is quite cold.

desc: If you are deliberate, you do something on purpose.
exam: Bernie made a deliberate attempt to injure Andy.

desc: To dissolve something is to mix it into a liquid and disappear.
exam: I dissolved the pill in a glass o f water.

desc: When something explodes, it blows up.
exam: My new radio exploded when I plugged it in.

desc: To fasten something is to close it or put it in the correct place.
exam: Elizabeth fastened her seat belt.

desc: A germ is something that makes you sick.
exam: Germs are on everything that you touch.

desc: A kit is a set of all the things needed to do something.
exam: Is there a first aid kit in your office?

desc: A puff is a little bit of smoke or steam.
exam: A puff of smoke came from the burnt match.

desc: A rag is a small towel.
exam: Please use a rag to clean the dust o ff the table.

desc: To scatter something is to make it go in many places.
exam: I accidentally scattered all of my pills.

desc: A scent is a smell.
exam: Julie enjoyed the scent of the flowers.

desc: Steel is a shiny gray metal.
exam: The new apartment building was made with steel.

desc: If something is swift, it is fast.
exam: The swift horse easily jumped over the hurdle.

desc: If you toss something, you throw it softly.
exam: He tossed a coin into the air.

desc: Triumph is what you feel when you win or finish something.
exam: He raised the award in triumph at the end of his speech.

desc: When someone is aboard a ship or plane, they are on or in it.
exam: They climbed aboard the kayak and paddled through the river.

desc: When a person is bitter, they are upset with someone or a situation.
exam: He was extremely bitter when his computer crashed.

desc: A bullet is a small metal object that is shot out of guns.
exam: Bullets come in different sizes for different guns.

desc: The devil is a powerful evil spirit in some religions.
exam: The church promised protection from the devil.

desc: To drift means to be moved slowly by wind or water.
exam: The large chunk of ice drifted in the water.

desc: To enforce means to make a person follow a rule.
exam: Police enforce traffic laws to keep everyone safe.

desc: A fountain is a source of water made by people.
exam: There was a beautiful fountain in the middle of the park.

desc: A harbor is an area of water along a shore where boats land.
exam: There were a few small boats in the harbor.

desc: To inhabit means to live in a certain place.
exam: No one inhabits the ancient city.

desc: To march means to walk at a steady pace together with others.
exam: The soldiers marched in straight rows.

desc: A millionaire is a person who has at least a million dollars.
exam: He became a millionaire because he was smart with his money.

desc: A port is a place where ships stop to load and unload things.
exam: The ship was being loaded with materials at the port.

desc: A sheriff is a police officer who is in charge of a large area.
exam: It was the sheriff’s job to make the city safe.

desc: To startle means to scare someone suddenly.
exam: The loud crash startled the sleeping woman.

desc: To sweat means to lose liquid from the body through the skin.
exam: Whenever I workout, I sweat quite a bit.

desc: A trigger is the part of the gun that a person pulls to make it fire.
exam: The man had his finger on the trigger of the gun.

desc: To unify means to bring people or things together.
exam: With their good deeds, the children tried to unify the world.

desc: A vessel is a large ship or boat.
exam: We toured the area aboard a luxury vessel.

desc: A voyage is a long journey made on a boat or an aircraft.
exam: The astronauts took off on a long voyage to the moon.

desc: To worship means to like and honor a person, thing, or religious figure.
exam: Many people around the world worship in a church.

desc: An apprentice is a person who learns how to do a job from a skilled person.
exam: Mark is an apprentice chef at the restaurant.

desc: To assure someone is to tell them something is true to make them less worried.
exam: He assured the boss that the building would be done on time.

desc: A bandage is a piece of cloth used to stop bleeding.
exam: If you cut yourself, please get a bandage from the first-aid kit.

desc: To bleed is to lose blood.
exam: If you are not careful, you will cut your finger and bleed.

desc: To bond with someone is to become friends with them.
exam: The women bonded after several hours of conversation.

desc: A chef is a person who cooks in a restaurant.
exam: Tom is a chef at the restaurant near my house.

desc: A crown is the hat worn by a king or queen.
exam: The crown is made of gold.

desc: A departure is the act of leaving a place.
exam: They were excited about their departure back home.

desc: If someone is diligent, they work hard and are careful.
exam: Craig has always been a very diligent person at work.

desc: An emperor is the leader of a group of countries.
exam: The emperor Julius Caesar was in control o f ancient Rome.

desc: Fiber is a thread of a substance used to make clothes or rope.
exam: The mat was made from tiny fibers.

desc: If something is horrible, it is very bad.
exam: The assignment was horrible. I hated it.

desc: If someone is impolite, they are rude.
exam: Roger is im polite to everyone he meets.

desc: To kneel is to put one or both knees on the ground.
exam: Daryl got down on one knee and asked Nina to marry him.

desc: A luxury is an expensive thing that you do not need.
exam: We stayed at a luxury resort for our honeymoon.

desc: If something is massive, it is very big.
exam: The wheels on his truck were massive.

desc: To panic is to feel so nervous or afraid that you cannot think clearly.
exam: Everyone panicked when the house caught on fire.

desc: A priority is something that is more important than other things.
exam: My priority is to get good grades in school.

desc: A robe is a long, loose piece of clothing.
exam: Many people wear robes in the morning.

desc: To scold means to criticize one angrily because they have done wrong.
exam: Jesse was scolded by the teacher for not paying attention.

desc: An affair is an event or a thing that happened.
exam: My wife and I attended a formal affair over the weekend.

desc: An assembly is a group that is together for the same reason.
exam: The students had an assembly to talk about their interests.

desc: To bless is to ask God for protection or help.
exam: The angel blessed the newborn baby to keep it safe.

desc: Cereal is a food that you mix with milk and eat for breakfast.
exam: Cereal is a fast and common breakfast food enjoyed in the U.S.

desc: If someone is cheerful, they are happy or feel good.
exam: The children were cheerful because they didn’t have to go to school.

desc: The diameter of a round thing is the length across its center.
exam: The diameter o f the tree was about 22 centimeters.

desc: To exploit something is to use it for greedy reasons rather than good reason.
exam: The company exploits their workers and makes them stay 12 hours a day.

desc: A famine is a long time with little or no food.
exam: The farmers couldn’t grow any food on the dry soil, so there was a famime.

desc: A harvest is the act of collecting food from farming.
exam: They had a lot of wheat from the last harvest.

desc: If someone is merry, they are very happy.
exam: They felt merry because the weather was great.

desc: A nut is a hard seed or fruit that comes from some trees and bushes.
exam: To eat a nut, first you have to crack its shell.

desc: To pardon is a way to ask someone to repeat what was said before.
exam: Pardon me teacher, but could you repeat what you just said?

desc: A pharaoh was a king in ancient Egypt.
exam: The pharaohs ruled Egypt for thousands of years.

desc: When a fruit is ripe, it is ready to be eaten.
exam: The cherries were nice and ripe.

desc: To roast something is to cook it in an oven or over a fire.
exam: Mom roasted a turkey for the holiday dinner.

desc: A routine is a way of doing things that is the same every time.
exam: My father’s daily routine includes shaving right before breakfast.

desc: A scheme is a plan or design.
exam: Mickey and Minnie came up with a scheme to solve the problem.

desc: If something or someone is slim, they are thin.
exam: Look at my new cell phone. It’s very slim.

desc: A stove is a device used to cook food.
exam: Our new stove helps us to cook food much faster than before.

desc: A theft is a criminal act that involves someone stealing something.
exam: The theft of his TV took place when he was at work.

desc: An adolescent is a young person or a teenager.
exam: The adolescent was excited about getting a skateboard for his birthday.

desc: Aptitude is a natural ability or skill.
exam: He has a natural aptitude for water skiing.

desc: To compliment is to say a nice thing about someone or something.
exam: Her co-worker complimented her for doing a good job.

desc: To hinder is to keep someone or something from doing something.
exam: All the traffic hindered me from getting to work on time.

desc: Journalism is the work of collecting the news to put in newspapers or on TV.
exam: Before becoming a teacher, she worked in journalism.

desc: A jury is a group of people that listen to a trial and say if someone is guilty.
exam: The jury listened closely to the attorney before they made their decision.

desc: Justice is fairness in the way that you treat other people.
exam: People turn to the court system when they are seeking justice.

desc: Liberty is freedom to do what you want.
exam: To many people, the Statue of Liberty is a symbol of freedom.

desc: If someone or something is literary, it is involved with literature in some way.
exam: He worked hard to create a successful literary career.

desc: A pharmacy is a place where medicine is sold.
exam: My mother sells medicine to people at the pharmacy.

desc: A pill is a small object that has medicine inside.
exam: She took a pill for her headache.

desc: To presume is to believe something is true without being certain.
exam: Since he raised his hand, the teacher presumed he knew the answer.

desc: To have privacy is to be away from other people.
exam: Please hang the sign on the door so we can have some privacy.

desc: A punishment is something that one must endure for any wrong doing.
exam: He was given a punishment for being rude to the teacher.

desc: If someone is sensible, they make good decisions.
exam: It was sensible for her to save some money each month.

desc: A slice is a piece from something larger, such as a cake.
exam: The girl enjoyed a slice of cake at her birthday party.

desc: Sorrow is a very sad feeling.
exam: The girl felt sorrow after her best friend moved away.

desc: A straw is a thin tube that is used to suck liquid into the mouth.
exam: I drank the orange juice through a straw.

desc: To swell is to become larger and rounder.
exam: My sister’s stomach began to swell after she got pregnant.

desc: When something is tidy, it is clean and in order.
exam: Leon has always been a very tidy boy.

desc: Affection is a feeling of liking someone or something.
exam: Amanda has a lot of affection for her little sister Sarah.

desc: An agency is a business or service set up to act for others.
exam: I went to a travel agency to help me arrange a flight home.

desc: Ash is the grey or black powder created when something is burned.
exam: The end of his cigar was full of ashes.

desc: To confine something is to keep it in one place.
exam: The elephant is confined to a cage in the zoo.

desc: To dismiss something is to say it is not important.
exam: He quickly dismissed my idea about a new project.

desc: To erupt is for a volcano or something to shoot a hot substance.
exam: The volcano erupted for the first time in ten years.

desc: Fate is a power that causes some things to happen.
exam: Some people believe that a person’s hand can tell their fate.

desc: Lava is the hot substance made of melted rock that shoots from volcanoes.
exam: The red hot lava poured from the volcano.

desc: If someone is miserable, they are very unhappy.
exam: He was miserable after his dog died.

desc: To navigate something is to control the way it moves or goes.
exam: She navigated the ship across the ocean.

desc: To originate somewhere is to start there.
exam: The idea of democracy originated in Ancient Greece.

desc: The remainder of something is what is left.
exam: He took a bite of the apple, then gave me the remainder of it.

desc: To retrieve something is to find it and get it back.
exam: She retrieved her mail from the mail box.

desc: If something is shallow, it is not deep.
exam: The kids were playing in the shallow water.

desc: A slope is ground that is not flat.
exam: The slope to the top of the mountain was very steep.

desc: To span a length of time is to last that long.
exam: His work began in 1999. It has spanned many years since then.

desc: A superstition is something magical that people believe is real.
exam: It is a superstition that Friday the 13th is an unlucky day.

desc: Sympathy is a feeling of being sad for another person.
exam: I felt sympathy for my sister so I got her a balloon to cheer her up.

desc: To vibrate is to shake very hard.
exam: The machine made his whole body vibrate as he broke up the ground.

desc: To wander is to walk without going to a certain place.
exam: The boys like to wander in the woods and look at birds.

desc: Armor is metal worn by soldiers to protect the body.
exam: The soldier wore armor to protect his body.

desc: To blaze means to burn brightly or powerfully.
exam: The small fire soon blazed into a large dangerous one.

desc: To boom means to make a loud, deep sound.
exam: The firecrackers made a loud boom when they exploded.

desc: A cliff is a high and often flat wall of rock.
exam: The wolf stood at the cliff and howled.

desc: A flame is part of fire.
exam: The torch was filled with yellow and orange flames.

desc: Independence is the state of being free from the control of others.
exam: After leaving home, Sophia had a great feeling of independence.

desc: An invasion is an attack by a group from another country.
exam: In Korea, walls were built around cities to protect them from invasions.

desc: A knight is a soldier of high rank and skill who usually serves a king.
exam: He was the best soldier, so the king made him a knight.

desc: Lightning is the bright light seen during a storm.
exam: The lightning flashed above the water.

desc: A rebel is a person who fights the government in order to change it.
exam: The rebel had enough of the government’s unfair polices.

desc: To retreat means to run away because you have been beaten in a fight.
exam: The army retreated because they were losing the battle.

desc: A revolution is a change to the political system by a group of people.
exam: The revolution in Russia led to the creation of the Soviet Union.

desc: A spear is a long stick with a blade on one end that is used as a weapon.
exam: The soldier was holding a spear in his hand.

desc: If something is steep, then its slope or angle rises or falls sharply.
exam: He rode his bike up the steep hill to reach the top.

desc: A summit is the highest part of a hill or mountain.
exam: Snow covered the summit of the mountain even during the summer.

desc: Thunder is the loud noise heard during a storm.
exam: The sound of the thunder startled me.

desc: Troops are soldiers that fight in groups in a battle.
exam: The troops were all prepared to go into battle.

desc: A warrior is a brave soldier or fighter.
exam: The samurai were some of the most skilled warriors in the ancient world.

desc: To withdraw means to leave a place, usually during war.
exam: After losing the battle, the enemy withdrew back to its own country.

desc: To yield something means to give up control of it or to give it away.
exam: He had to yield his turn because he was in checkmate.

desc: A bench is a long seat for two or more people.
exam: Most parks have benches for citizens to relax upon.

desc: To confront a hard situation or person is to deal with it.
exam: The couple has to confront each other about their problems.

desc: A daisy is a small flower with white petals and a yellow center.
exam: There were a few daisies growing in the field.

desc: A dispute is an argument or disagreement that people have.
exam: Karen and Brian often have disputes about silly things.

desc: Horror is a feeling of being very afraid or shocked.
exam: The audience screamed in horror when the ghost appeared in the movie.

desc: An incident is an event that is usually not pleasant.
exam: Mr. Wilson had an incident where he became sick and had to leave.

desc: Mist is water that you can see in the air or on a surface.
exam: The forest was covered with mist.

desc: An object is an inanimate thing that you can see or touch.
exam: The shopping cart was filled with objects.

desc: An orphan is a child who does not have parents.
exam: The orphan frequently cried during the night.

desc: To plot is to make a secret plan to do something that is wrong or mean.
exam: The group was plotting to ruin the company’s financial reports.

desc: When a female is pregnant, she is going to have a baby.
exam: The pregnant woman was shopping for baby clothes.

desc: Rage is a very angry feeling.
exam: The chef was filled with rage when his helpers ruined the meal.

desc: Revenge is what you do to hurt or punish someone who hurts you.
exam: He broke his sister’s doll as revenge after she lost his favorite book.

desc: Shame is a bad feeling about things you have done wrong.
exam: The boy felt shame about misplacing his clothes.

desc: To sigh is to breathe out loudly and show that you are tired or sad.
exam: Molly sighed when she looked at all the information she had to research.

desc: To sneak is to move quietly so that no one hears or sees you.
exam: The thief snuck out of the house without anyone noticing him.

desc: To spare something is to give it because you have more than you need.
exam: I wanted to help him but I couldn’t spare a tire.

desc: The stem of a plant is the stick that grows leaves or flowers.
exam: The rose had a long thin stem.

desc: Supper is a meal that is eaten in the evening.
exam: We usually have supper around 6 o ’clock at my house.

desc: When something is tender, it is soft and easy to chew.
exam: The meat was so tender they didn’t need knives to cut it with.

desc: If something is beneath something else, it is under it.
exam: The largest part of an iceberg lies beneath the waterline.

desc: A cub is a baby animal, such as a bear or lion.
exam: The lion cub was crying for its mother.

desc: Dawn is the time of day when the sun rises.
exam: At dawn, the sun gently rose over the farm.

desc: If you are dissatisfied, you are not happy with something.
exam: I was dissatisfied with their decision to work on Sunday.

desc: When something is done with ease, it is not hard to do.
exam: The monkey climbed the tree with ease.

desc: When something is evident, it is easy to see or understand.
exam: It was evident from the look on his face that he was unhappy.

desc: Hail is ice that falls from the sky when rain freezes.
exam: The hail from the storm was the size of golf balls.

desc: To howl means to make a long, loud sound like a wolf or a dog.
exam: The wolf howled at the moon.

desc: To leap means to jump a long distance.
exam: He had to leap over the gap to reach the other side of the hill.

desc: When something is magnificent, it is beautiful and grand.
exam: The man gave his wife a pair of magnificent diamond earrings.

desc: A necessity is something that is needed.
exam: Fresh water is a necessity for life.

desc: An outcome is the end of an action or event.
exam: The outcome of his latest business plan was a complete failure.

desc: A pile is a large group of things on top of one another.
exam: The pile of cups was beginning to tilt.

desc: When something is profound, it is very intelligent.
exam: For a little boy, Jeremy has some profound thoughts.

desc: To seize something means to grab it quickly or strongly.
exam: The man seized as much money as he could before anyone could see him.

desc: To squeeze something means to press it together and hold it tightly.
exam: When Clara saw her cat, she gave it a big squeeze.

desc: When something is supreme, it is the highest or best.
exam: The supreme officer was in charge of keeping the citizens calm.

desc: When something is terrific, it is very good.
exam: My youngest daughter is a terrific painter.

desc: A trait is part of someone’s personality.
exam: One trait of Salvador’s personality is his cheerfulness.

desc: When something is vital, it is necessary for life.
exam: The heart is a vital organ.

desc: When you become accustomed to something, you are in the habit of it.
exam: Grandfather is accustomed to reading the newspaper every morning.

desc: To affirm is to say that something is true.
exam: Using a graph, Malcolm affirmed the success o f the company.

desc: If someone is astonished, they are very surprised or shocked.
exam: I was astonished when he pulled the live rabbit out of his hat.

desc: To bang is to hit something to make a noise.
exam: The drummer banged on his drum as he marched in the parade.

desc: A clan is a group of relatives or friends.
exam: The Lee clan meets every year to celebrate the New Year.

desc: When something is dim, it does not give out much light.
exam: Working in a dim room is bad for your eyes.

desc: Emphasis is special attention or importance.
exam: The students put special emphasis on chapter 4 because it will be on the test.

desc: A fable is a short story that teaches a lesson.
exam: In the fable about the tortoise and the hare, the lesson is consistency.

desc: A feast is a large meal for many people.
exam: At Thanksgiving, I enjoy a wonderful feast with my family.

desc: To glow is to make a soft light.
exam: The small flame glowed softly.

desc: When something is hollow, it has an empty space inside.
exam: Straws are hollow, so liquid can flow through them.

desc: Instinct is the natural way that people behave without thinking about it.
exam: Cats hunt mice because of instinct.

desc: A joint is a place of the body where the bones meet, such as the knee.
exam: Two important bones in your leg meet at a join t in your knee.

desc: To leak is to let a liquid or gas pass through a flaw.
exam: The pipe leaks from many places.

desc: A physician is a doctor.
exam: The physician said I would feel better if I took my medicine.

desc: To sacrifice something valuable is to give it up to get something else.
exam: Her parents sacrificed a lot of money in order for her to go to college.

desc: When something is stiff, it is hard to move.
exam: The bird was standing on the tree’s s tiff branch.

desc: To stroke is to move a hand over something or someone.
exam: She stroked her cheek to see if there was something on it.

desc: When something is tragic, it is connected with death and suffering.
exam: The airplane crashed in a tragic accident.

desc: A tune is a song.
exam: The students played a familiar tune for the audience.

desc: To accommodate is to have enough room.
exam: The meeting room can accommodate nine people.

desc: A circus is a traveling show with animals and people.
exam: I like to go to the circus to see the animals do tricks.

desc: If two things coincide, they happen at the same time.
exam: My birthday coincides with Christmas.

desc: To commission someone to do something is to pay them to do it.
exam: The artist was commissioned to create a picture.

desc: A dose is a certain amount of medicine that you take at one time.
exam: My mother gave me a dose of medicine before I went to bed.

desc: To dye something is to make it a certain color by using a special chemical.
exam: Valery got her hair dyed at the salon yesterday.

desc: The extent of something is how large, important, or serious it is.
exam: He ate to such an extent that he became overweight.

desc: Gender is a category that describes being either a boy or a girl.
exam: Do you know the gender of her new baby?

desc: A headline is the title of a newspaper story.
exam: The headline on the front page was about the economy.

desc: When something is informal, it is not official.
exam: They had an informal meeting to talk about their experiences.

desc: To inquire about something is to ask about it.
exam: Dad called to inquire about the price of tickets for the show.

desc: A messenger is one who carries information from one place to another.
exam: The messenger delivered an important document to the office.

desc: To peer at something is to watch it carefully.
exam: She peered at people through the window.

desc: A portrait is a painting or photograph of someone.
exam: I saw many religious portraits when I went to the museum.

desc: To pose is to stay in one place without moving.
exam: The kids and their dog posed for a picture.

desc: A ranch is a large farm where animals are kept.
exam: My uncle has many horses on his ranch.

desc: To steer something is to control where it goes.
exam: He steered the go-cart around the track.

desc: A stripe is a thick line.
exam: The flag of the United States has red and white stripes.

desc: When an animal is tame, it is not afraid to be near people.
exam: The tame bird rested on his hand.

desc: To tempt people is to offer them something they want but shouldn’t have.
exam: I wasn’t hungry, but she tempted me with a piece of my favorite cake.

desc: An Aborigine is a native of Australia before Europeans lived there.
exam: The Aborigines created beautiful artwork.

desc: To ban something is to not let people do it.
exam: Smoking is banned in this building.

desc: If you are cautious, you are careful in a dangerous situation.
exam: Be very cautious as you stack those boxes.

desc: To confess something is to say that you did it.
exam: He confessed that he was responsible for choosing the winning story.

desc: A cottage is a small, old house in the countryside.
exam: My aunt lives in a pretty cottage in the mountains.

desc: Daytime is the time of the day when the sky is light.
exam: I only allowed my kids to play outside in the daytime.

desc: If you are desperate, you will try anything to do or change something.
exam: I’m desperate to find a new job.

desc: If something fades, it gets quieter or darker.
exam: The piece of cloth I found was old and faded.

desc: If a person or animal is fierce, they are angry or violent.
exam: Wolves are fierce animals. Do not disturb them.

desc: To gamble means to play a game that involves winning or losing money.
exam: Many people like to go to casinos to gamble.

desc: A lawn is an area covered in grass.
exam: My dad keeps the lawn in front of our house very neat.

desc: To mow grass is to cut it to make it very short.
exam: I mow our lawn every weekend.

desc: An outlaw is a criminal who hides from the police.
exam: The police passed out posters of the outlaw to all the people.

desc: A prospect is a possibility that something will happen.
exam: He wakes up every morning with the prospect of having a good day.

desc: A purse is a bag where women keep money, makeup and keys.
exam: My sister likes to buy designer purses.

desc: A rod is a thin stick made of wood or metal.
exam: I bought a new fishing rod to use while on vacation.

desc: If something seldom happens, it doesn’t happen very often.
exam: It seldom rains in southern Arizona.

desc: To shave means to cut the hairs on your face with a sharp tool.
exam: My father shaves his face every day because he doesn’t want a beard.

desc: If you are terrified, you are extremely scared.
exam: When I saw the ghost, I was absolutely terrified!

desc: A wizard is a man who can do magic.
exam: The wizard made gold fall from the sky.

desc: Baggage is the set of bags that people take with them when they travel.
exam: I’m taking several pieces of baggage with me on vacation.

desc: A bulb is the glass part of an electric light.
exam: I had to change the light bulb in my bedroom.

desc: A bundle is a number of things that are tied together.
exam: I was shocked when he showed me a bundle of money.

desc: Cattle are cows and bulls, especially on a farm.
exam: The rancher’s cattle were eating the grass in the field.

desc: To flee means to run away from trouble or danger.
exam: The crowd of men tried to flee from the danger.

desc: To graze means to eat grass.
exam: The cows grazed in the field.

desc: Greed is a desire to have more than the things that you need.
exam: She ate all the cookies out of her greed.

desc: A herd is a large group of the same type of animals that live together.
exam: The herd of cows moved slowly across the ranch.

desc: To initiate something means to start it.
exam: You have to turn the switch on to initiate the computer system.

desc: A lane is a small road.
exam: The lane passes directly in front of our house.

desc: Nerve is bravery or the belief that you can do something.
exam: He has the nerve to think that he can actually wrestle with a lion.

desc: An optimist is somebody who sees the good parts of a situation.
exam: Even though he has physical problems, my brother is an optimist.

desc: A parade is a celebration when groups of people walk in the same direction.
exam: There were many marching bands in the spring parade.

desc: To pave the ground is to lay material on it to make it easier to walk or drive on.
exam: The path was paved with yellow bricks.

desc: A phantom is a ghost or spirit.
exam: A scary phantom appeared from out of the darkness.

desc: Something that is portable is able to be moved or carried easily.
exam: Since computers are portable, people can use them anywhere.

desc: A poster is a written announcement that is used to advertise something.
exam: I saw a poster about a free concert in the park.

desc: To scratch is to make small cuts with a claw or fingernail.
exam: I used a stick to scratch my back.

desc: A symphony is a long piece of music performed by many musicians.
exam: Alex, a violin player, has always dreamt of playing a symphony.

desc: A widow is a woman whose husband has died.
exam: The widow had no children and was very lonely.

desc: To circulate something is to spread it quickly.
exam: The fan helped to circulate cool air through the room.

desc: Consequent means happening because of a different situation.
exam: Her consequent rash came after she touched the poison ivy.

desc: To derive something from another source means to get it from that thing.
exam: Red’s nickname was derived from the color of her hair.

desc: To drown is to die from not being able to breathe underwater.
exam: He would have drowned if the sailors would not have rescued him.

desc: A dynasty is a series of rulers who are all from the same family.
exam: The ancient Egyptians had a dynasty that lasted for many years.

desc: A fraction is a small part of something.
exam: Only a fraction of the cake was gone.

desc: Frost is a white layer of ice that forms during very cold weather.
exam: In the morning, the trees were all covered with frost.

desc: An illusion is something that looks real, but doesn’t actually exist.
exam: Some pictures create an illusion for the eyes.

desc: To invade is to take over a place by force.
exam: The enemy forces tried to invade our country through the air.

desc: A lieutenant is a rank in the military or police, or a person with that rank.
exam: The lieutenant was a good leader, and his soldiers respected him.

desc: The word marine describes something related to the sea.
exam: A healthy ocean is full of marine animals.

desc: The merit of something or someone is their good qualities.
exam: The actor received an award for his merits in the movie.

desc: A navy is the part of a country’s military that fights at sea.
exam: My country is known for our strong navy.

desc: Polar relates to the cold places on Earth’s north and south ends.
exam: Only a few people live in the Earth’s northern polar region.

desc: A ray is a line of light that comes from a bright object.
exam: The sun’s warm rays covered the beach.

desc: To resign means to quit a job.
exam: After I officially resigned from work, I said goodbye to my boss.

desc: Suicide is the act of killing oneself.
exam: Some people feel so sad that they think suicide is the only answer.

desc: To tremble is to shake as a result of cold weather.
exam: Harry was not used to the cold, so he trembled most of the day.

desc: When something is underlying, it is a hidden cause of something else.
exam: Her underlying fear of flying reduced her traveling options.

desc: To travel via something means to travel through or using something.
exam: We arrived in the city from the airport via the train.

desc: To alter something means to make a small change to it.
exam: I altered the color of my nails to match my hair.

desc: If someone stands aside, they are on or to one side.
exam: The man stood aside and opened the door for me.

desc: Autumn is the season of the year between summer and winter.
exam: I love when the leaves fall in autumn because I can play in them.

desc: To blend is to mix two or more things together so that they become one thing.
exam: My wife blended together all of the ingredients to make a delicious stew.

desc: To collapse is to fall down suddenly.
exam: The tree collapsed right in front of our house.

desc: To crush something is to press it together so its shape is destroyed.
exam: Selena’s new car was crushed when something fell on top of it.

desc: To curve is to move in a line that bends and does not go straight.
exam: The road curves to the left and to the right.

desc: If something is disgusting, it is very unpleasant.
exam: After running all day, Greg’s feet had a disgusting odor.

desc: A drain is a pipe that carries away water from a building, such as in a kitchen.
exam: The water in the sink goes down the drain as you wash your hands.

desc: To embrace is to hug.
exam: When they saw each other again, the happy couple embraced.

desc: To envy someone is to wish that you had something that they have.
exam: Sally envied the happy couple.

desc: Fireworks are objects that create colored lights when they are lit.
exam: The display of fireworks was so beautiful.

desc: Flour is a powder made from plants that is used to make foods like bread.
exam: I wanted to bake a pie, but I needed flour.

desc: A fuse is a string that you light on fireworks to make them explode.
exam: The boy litthe fuse on the rocket and waited for it to burst in the sky.

desc: Ginger is a spice from the root of a plant. It tastes spicy and sweet.
exam: Ginger is a common ingredient in many dishes from India.

desc: If you are jealous, you think someone might take something from you.
exam: Miriam was jealous because Sue was paying too much attention to Jim .

desc: A paste is a thick and smooth substance.
exam: My son needed some paste for a school project.

desc: A receipt is a paper that proves that something was received or bought.
exam: After looking at my receipt, I realized that I had spent too much money.

desc: To wipe something is to slide a piece of cloth over it to clean it.
exam: She wiped the dust from the windows.

desc: A wire is a thin string made out of metal.
exam: The wires were connected to towers that brought electricity to the city.

desc: If you acknowledge something, you accept that it is true or that it exists.
exam: The teacher acknowledged that the young student was hungry.

desc: An ambassador is a government worker who works in another country.
exam: The ambassador from Korea was in charge ofthe conference.

desc: If someone is a blonde, they have light-colored hair.
exam: My cousin is different from me. She is a blonde with blue eyes.

desc: To conquer a country means to attack and take control of it.
exam: The soldiers were trying to conquer the world.

desc: To drag something means to pull it across the ground.
exam: The dog was dragging his owner down the street.

desc: To exaggerate is to say that something is bigger or better than it really is.
exam: Jimmy wasn’t exaggerating about the seriousness of his injury.

desc: Heritage is the collection of features of a society, such as language and religion.
exam: Teepees are part ofthe heritage of the American Indians of the plains.

desc: To insult someone is to say things that will hurt their feelings.
exam: The girls insulted each other all afternoon.

desc: Meanwhile means until something happens or while something is happening.
exam: He wants to be a doctor in the future, but meanwhile, he works a regular job.

desc: A necklace is a piece of jewelry that people wear around their necks.
exam: Joyce received a lovely pearl necklace for her wedding anniversary.

desc: A noble is a rich and powerful person.
exam: The Queen invited a noble from a nearby country to dinner.

desc: When something is precious, it is valuable and important.
exam: In a desert, water can be more precious than money.

desc: A prejudice is an unfair opinion about someone before you get to know them.
exam: The company’s rules against gender prejudice must be enforced.

desc: A rumor is a story that may not be true.
exam: Carla was spreading rumors around the office.

desc: A sin is something that is wrong for religious reasons.
exam: Taking something that doesn’t belong to you is a sin.

desc: A spectacle is an amazing sight.
exam: Niagara Falls is quite a spectacle.

desc: A stack is a pile of different things.
exam: There was a stack of paperwork on his desk to complete.

desc: If someone is suspicious of someone else, they do not trust that person.
exam: Dad was suspicious ofthe caller on the line.

desc: Tin is a cheap white metal.
exam: Soup is a common food that is often sold in tin cans.

desc: A vase is an attractive container where people keep flowers.
exam: The vase was filled with such lovely flowers.

desc: If something aches, it hurts.
exam: Mindy’s head ached because she bumped it against the wall.

desc: If something is arctic, it is from far north near the North Pole.
exam: It is cold when the arctic winds blow.

desc: A canal is a path for water to travel through.
exam: The city of Venice, Italy, has many canals.

desc: A chemist is a scientist who works with chemicals.
exam: My mother is a successful chemist who helps invent new products.

desc: A chill is a feeling of cold.
exam: The chill from the cold wind made Bill shiver.

desc: Congress is a group of leaders in a government.
exam: Congress makes laws for people to follow.

desc: If something is dairy, it is made from milk.
exam: Things like milk and cheese are dairy foods.

desc: To descend is to go downward.
exam: I descended the stairs to get out of the building.

desc: A grocer is a person who sells food.
exam: Our grocer, Mr. Smith, is a very kind man.

desc: To hesitate is to wait for a short time before doing something.
exam: He hesitated for a moment before he decided which choice to make.

desc: An institution is an organization that works to help a city or group of people.
exam: Banks are vital institutions that businesses and people use every day.

desc: To jog is to run slowly.
exam: He jogs every day so he can be healthier.

desc: A merchant is a person who sells things.
exam: The merchant was selling used cars.

desc: To poke something is to push it with your finger.
exam: I poked my finger on a thumb tack.

desc: To postpone something is to make it happen later than planned.
exam: They postponed the meeting until Elena arrived.

desc: When a liquid splashes, it bursts and hits something.
exam: Some green paint splashed upon the floor.

desc: If people are stubborn, they don’t change their minds easily.
exam: Both of my parents are stubborn. They never give in to each other.

desc: A suburb is a small part of a large city.
exam: I grew up in the suburbs only a few minutes outside of the city.

desc: The tide is the level of the water in the sea.
exam: The tide continued to crawl upon the beach little by little.

desc: A tragedy is a very sad event.
exam: It was a tragedy when his house was struck by lightning and burned.

desc: A bomb is an object that explodes and destroys large areas.
exam: The bomb will destroy anything that is near.

desc: A certificate is a document that says that something is true or happened.
exam: I was given a certificate after completing the computer course.

desc: A circumstance is an event that makes a situation what it is.
exam: There were many circumstances behind their success like hard work.

desc: A coffin is a box used to bury dead people.
exam: When a person passes away, they are usually buried inside of a coffin.

desc: To cope with a difficult or stressful situation means to deal with it.
exam: He copes with work stress by exercising three or four times a week.

desc: Criticism is the act of saying that you don’t like or approve of something.
exam: She had a lot of criticism about their new plan.

desc: To devastate something means to completely destroy it.
exam: The entire wall was devastated.

desc: To frown is to make an unhappy look with your face.
exam: Melissa frowned when she found out that the party had been cancelled.

desc: To gaze at something means to look at it for a long time.
exam: We used a telescope to gaze at the stars for over an hour.

desc: To glance at something means to look at it quickly.
exam: She glanced behind her to see if he was looking at her.

desc: Grief is the feeling of deep sadness, usually when a person dies.
exam: The grief caused by losing her parents was very difficult for her.

desc: A groom is a man who is going to be married.
exam: The groom looked happy as he walked with his new wife.

desc: A license is an official document that gives one permission to do something.
exam: In the United States you need a driver’s license to drive legally.

desc: A microscope is a device that makes small objects look bigger.
exam: Germs cannot be seen without a microscope.

desc: When something is nuclear, it relates to the division or joining of atoms.
exam: Nuclear power plants provide inexpensive energy to cities.

desc: To portray something means to describe it or show it in a picture.
exam: Her picture portrayed the house she grew up in when she was little.

desc: To rotate something means to turn it around in a circle.
exam: An airplane’s propellers rotate quickly to help it fly.

desc: A souvenir is something you buy to remind you of a place or event.
exam: I bought a Russian doll as a souvenir from my trip to Moscow.

desc: A submarine is a boat that can go underwater for long periods of time.
exam: The submarine dove under the sea so the enemy couldn’t see it.

desc: To trace something means to follow over it with the eyes or a finger.
exam: He traced over the graph with his finger.

desc: An appliance is a piece of equipment used for jobs in the home.
exam: Many homes have appliances like ovens, toasters and refrigerators.

desc: A basin is large bowl for washing things. A sink is sometimes called a basin.
exam: She filled the basin with water and washed her face.

desc: A broom is a brush with a long handle used for cleaning floors.
exam: My father usually uses a broom to sweep away dust in the basement.

desc: A caterpillar is a small insect that looks like a worm and eats plants.
exam: After eating a lot of leaves, caterpillars change into butterflies.

desc: A cupboard is a piece of furniture that is used to store food or household items.
exam: We put all of our dishes and food in the cupboards.

desc: If something or someone is delicate, they are easy to break or harm.
exam: You should hold the baby carefully because she’s very delicate.

desc: To emerge from something means to come out of it.
exam: The hand suddenly emerged from the grave.

desc: A handicap is a condition that limits someone’s mental or physical abilities.
exam: Joe has a slight handicap, so he uses a walker to get around.

desc: A hook is a sharp curved piece of metal used for catching or holding things.
exam: The fish went after the sharp hook.

desc: To hop means to jump a short distance.
exam: The kangaroo quickly hopped away from danger.

desc: Laundry is clothes that have been or need to be washed.
exam: He folded the clean laundry and put the dirty laundry in a basket.

desc: To pursue someone or something is to chase or follow them.
exam: The mother pursued her young child down the hill.

desc: If someone is reluctant, they do not want to do something.
exam: She was reluctant to eat the meager breakfast.

desc: Sleeves are the part of a shirt where your arms go.
exam: Ryan bought a new shirt with long sleeves to keep his arms warm.

desc: The spine is the bone that runs up and down the middle of the back.
exam: Our spine helps us to stand up nice and straight.

desc: A stain is a dirty mark that is difficult to clean.
exam: He had a red stain on the collar of his shirt.

desc: A strip is a long, narrow piece of material or land.
exam: He had long strips of film that held images of his trip abroad.

desc: To swear means to promise to do something.
exam: I will put my hand on the Bible and swear to do my best for the country.

desc: To swing something means to move it back and forth or from side to side.
exam: He can swing a golf club very powerfully.

desc: To utilize something means to use it for a specific purpose.
exam: They utilized a pair of scissors to cut the ribbon.
